titlepage.titleproper:
Finding aid for
Chrystal G. Tibbs Papers, 1913-2013
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Lauren Murtagh, September 2013

did.abstract: The Chrystal G. Tibbs Papers comprise over a half-century of documents pertaining to Tibbs's membership in various chapters of the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority and to the history of the sorority at large. Founded at Howard University in 1908, A.K.A. was the first sorority established by African-American women and currently has approximately 250,000 members. The collection's six series contain papers pertaining to Tibbs's personal participation in sorority activities (including those related to her tenure in various administrative posts), materials from several Michigan chapters, sorority publications, and audiovisual materials.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The records were donated to the library by Dr. Chrystal G. Tibbs (Donor No. 10957) in 2013.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Chrystal G. Tibbs Papers , Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Dr. Chrystal Tibbs is a retired elementary school administrator and lifetime member of the Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority. A longtime Michigan resident, Tibbs spent her career in the Detroit Public School system and has been active in numerous Michigan chapters of A.K.A. for five decades. Chrystal Garrell Powell Tibbs was born on May 17th, 1932, in Williamsport, Pennsylvania to Robert Bernard Powell and Maggie Winchester Winstead Powell. Tibbs graduated valedictorian of her class at the Charles Sumner School in Parkersburg, West Virginia in 1949. She subsequently attended Bluefield State College (1949-51) and Oberlin College (1951-52) before obtaining her B.S. in Elementary Education in 1955 from Wayne State University. She earned a Master's of Education in 1962, also from Wayne State, followed by a Master of Arts in Library Science from the University of Michigan in 1968 and a PhD in Education from Michigan State University in 1974. Tibbs served in administrative capacities at various Detroit elementary schools and as Principal of Hampton Elementary School.

Membership in the Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority spans multiple generations of Tibbs's family; her mother, three maternal aunts, three sisters, and two daughters have all been members. Tibbs first became a member of A.K.A. in 1950 while at Bluefield State College, where she was inducted into the Beta Omicron chapter. Upon her marriage and subsequent move to Detroit, Tibbs became a member of the Alpha Rho Omega chapter, for which she was later elected to the offices of Anti-Basileus (Vice President), Epistoleus (Corresponding Secretary), and Member at Large. In 1991 Tibbs became a charter member of the Tau Alpha Omega chapter of Redford, Michigan, where she has served as Basileus (President), Anti-Basileus, and Philacter (Sergeant at Arms). In 2008 Tibbs served as President of the Vision Fair Foundation, a charitable organization under the auspices of the Tau Alpha Omega chapter.

Tibbs became a Golden Soror (50 year member of A.K.A.) in 2000 and was awarded the Golden Soror of the Year award in 2009. She has been a delegate to dozens of regional and national conferences and events over a fifty-year span. Tibbs was appointed Great Lakes Regional Representative to the International Archives Committee of A.K.A. in 2009, a post to which she has been reappointed twice and which she will hold until 2014. In this capacity Tibbs has worked to educate A.K.A. members with regard to archival practice and preservation of the history of the sorority, its chapters, and its membership.

scopecontent.p: The Chrystal G. Tibbs Papers comprise materials accumulated through Tibbs's participation in Alpha Kappa Alpha conferences, chapter meetings, and special interest groups at the local, state, regional, and national level over a span of fifty years. The activities of Michigan-based chapters are particularly well represented. The collection is divided into five series: Personal Papers and Artifacts, A.K.A. National and Regional Activities, Michigan Chapter Activities, Publications, and Audiovisual Materials.

scopecontent.p: The Personal Papers and Artifacts series (0.9 linear feet) is divided into four subseries: A.K.A. Membership Papers, Awards, and the Maggie Powell Papers. The first subseries is composed of certificates of membership and merit, notes and photographs from conferences and events Tibbs attended, and a scrapbook celebrating Tibbs's educational, professional, and A.K.A.-related achievements. The second subseries contains placards and trophies Tibbs was awarded in recognition of her long-term service to the sorority. The last subseries contains the papers of Tibbs's mother, Maggie Powell, who became a member of A.K.A. in 1925. These include certificates, speeches, press clippings, and photographs. The last subseries is unrelated to Alpha Kappa Alpha and predominantly consists of ephemera and mid-20th century photographs from a Detroit church which Tibbs attended.

Reverend H.A. Stines, program and clippings 1964
Guild of the Christ Child, invitation to Tibbs's daughter Nadine 1954

scopecontent.p: The A.K.A. National and Regional Activities series (0.8 linear feet) is divided into three subseries: National Level Activities and Documents, A.K.A. International Archives Committee (I.A.C.), and the Great Lakes Region. The first subseries includes policy documents, programs and ephemera from national events (particularly Boules), photographs, and newspaper clippings. The second subseries contains papers pertaining to the sorority's national and regional efforts to preserve its history, as well as documents from Tibbs's tenure as Great Lakes Regional Representative to the I.A.C. Such documents include histories, conference presentations, and committee meeting proceedings. The third subseries is composed of materials related to activities of A.K.A.'s Great Lakes Region, including Great Lakes Regional Conferences and regional histories.

A.K.A. Sorority Great Lakes Region: Through the Years, by Bella G. Clinkscale, 1985

scopecontent.p: The Michigan Chapter Activities series (1.3 linear feet) is divided into four subseries: Statewide Activities, the Tau Alpha Omega Chapter, the Alpha Rho Omega Chapter, and Other Michigan Chapters. The first subseries contains programs of events, such as the Michigan Cluster Conference, and obituaries of Michigan members. The second subseries is comprised of events programs, membership rosters, and documents from Tibbs's tenure as Basileus of the Tau Alpha Omega Chapter of Redford, Michigan. The latter documents include meeting minutes, annual reports, and records regarding charitable initiatives. The third subseries is predominantly comprised of events programs and ephemera from the Alpha Rho Omega Chapter of Detroit. The fourth subseries contains documents, events programs, and ephemera from thirteen other Michigan chapters, which are arranged in alphabetical order.

scopecontent.p: The Publications series (0.7 linear feet) is comprised of two subseries: Ivy Leaf Magazine and Books. The former subseries contains issues of A.K.A.'s national publication entitled the Ivy Leaf. The latter subseries contains books published by A.K.A. and devoted to the topics of the sorority's early history, its notable members, and the professional and political accomplishments of African-American women.

scopecontent.p: The Audiovisual Materials series (0.3 linear feet) contains media in a variety of formats, including VHS, DVD, and CD-ROM. The VHS tapes and DVD consist of short films commemorating A.K.A.'s history, while the more numerous CD-ROMs contain information about Boules, campaign presentations of prospective Basilei, and information about archival practices undertaken to document the sorority's history. The series also contains one record of A.K.A. sorority songs.
